subject: Tasty, not Testy, Testing
header: On the menu this week: minor releases of perl to address the rehashing flaw recently discovered. Plus a few articles dealing with tests; how to manage them efficiently, and how work around those that cause us grief.

entries.text: New releases addressing the recently discovered rehashing flaw.
entries.title: Perl 5.16.3 and 5.14.4 just released

entries.text: Strawberry Perl echoes the core mothership and releases two new versions addressing the rehashing flaw.
entries.title: Strawberry Perl (for Windows) 5.16.3.1 + 5.14.4.1 released

entries.text: Andy Lester doesn't have the time required to work on perl101.org, and need somebody to take on the torch. Could that be you?
entries.title: perl101.org needs a new maintainer

entries.text: Oh dearie me, you wanted to submit a talk for YAPC::NA, but forgot about the deadline? You're in luck: the staff kinda did the same. Clear outcome: the deadline is extended till the end of the month.
entries.title: YAPC::NA Austin - Call for speakers extended to end of month

entries.text: PrePAN, a platform available to discuss new Perl module ideas, is now AWS hosted, and in a move that promise synergic goodness, their team has joined the MetaCPAN team.
entries.title: PrePAN module discussion project

entries.text: The Perl News, Leo Lapworth let us know, is looking for stories, events, milestones pertaining to Perl. Have something to share, hop on IRC and tell them your stories.
entries.title: Perl News - let us know about your big story

entries.text: The last release of cpanm added the version of the running perl to cpanm's user-agent signature. miyagawa compiled the results for our pie-viewing pleasure.
entries.title: Perl versions usage stats (with cpanm)

entries.text: Did you know that you can upgrade your perl via perlbrew without having to reinstall all of your libraries? If not, chromatic will show you how.
entries.title: Upgrade in Place with Perlbrew

entries.text: Several activities streams converge in Oylenshpeegul's entry, in which the discussion about improving CPAN/Github interaction, the newest cpanm features, and a bug in Config::Simple all crash together.
entries.title: Perl modules on CPAN and github

entries.text: Perl5i is an experimental fork of perl spearheaded by Schwern where features long-desired but problematic, usualy because of the need for backward-compatibility, are gleefully injected in the language. Intrigued?  With this new quickstart guide, it is now much easier for you to experience this alternate-reality perl first-hand...
entries.title: Perl5i Quickstart Guide

entries.text: Joel Berger professes his love for the ever-vigilant CPANtesters, as well as for a (relative) newcomer in the Open Source testing scene, Travis-CI, and narrates how they both helping him troubleshoot his spiffy Galileo CMS project.
entries.title: I love CPANtesters and Travis-CI

entries.text: You have so many tests associated with your perl code that it's becoming a problem to wade through it in search of a specific testcase?  Oh, how do I envy you. But still, Ovid proposes a standard (with heplful vim scripts) to  make things as neat and as organized as possible.
entries.title: Discoverable tests and creating testing standards

entries.text: Some authors bundle POD tests in their distribution, which has little value  to the end-user. David Golden got tired of those, and introduces a new test harness that transparently skip those pesky tests.
entries.title: Stop Pod tests before they stop you!

entries.text: Just like Moose can tremendously simplify your OO classes, Test:::Class::Moose can do wonders for your test suites. Ovid shows us how it can leverage inheritance and roles to great advantages.
entries.title: Using Roles with Test::Class::Moose

entries.text: Never underestimate the power of a well-placed "thank you".  David Golden shows how one can easily, and automatically, give credit to everyone who contribute to a distribution, with a little bit of Dist::Zilla help.
entries.title: How I'm using Dist::Zilla to give credit to contributors

entries.text: Toby Inkster proposes a new way to declare that a module would only run on certain platforms.
entries.title: Introducing Platform

entries.text: How do you know when a CORE module is deprecated? brian d foy tells you where to look to figure it out.
entries.title: Deprecated modules warn when they are used

entries.text: Sawyer X's vouches that reading his blog entry will open your eyes to the wonderful world of deferred promises. I vow he's right.
entries.title: Recursive deferred promises

entries.text: Ben Bullock announces a new version of Text::Fuzzy, a module that has nothing to do with ursine muppets, and eveverything with dealing with text written by humans, and thus subject to msitakes.
entries.title: Text::Fuzzy now with transpositions

chapters.title: Events
chapters.header: I usually list the next 3-4 events here. The list of all the events can be found on the web site. If your Perl event is not listed there, please let me know.
